CSS Selectors

Introduction

CSS Selectors are patterns used to select HTML elements to be styled. Such patterns may be formed by a variety of characteristics of the element:

  • The element itself
  • Class
  • Id
  • Attributes
  • Pseudo-class (hovered, active link, etc)
CSS Versions

CSS levels 1 and 2 are built-in on CSS3, the current version. CSS1 was the initial definition, which defined the terminology of the language and the syntax for the rules.

CSS2 was developed over CSS1 and introduced new concepts such as absolute, relative, and fixed positioning of elements; media types and new properties for fonts.

CSS3 introduced a lot of new pseudo-classes and made major improvements on elements' borders. CSS3 has been divided in modules, making it's use simpler.

Without giving much detail on CSS versions, one thing must be kept in mind: the language is still under development and with enough time, new features (like selectors for parent elements) will be added.

Syntax

The basic syntax of a CSS rule is as follows:

selector { property: value; }
Selector Categories

Selectors can be divided into 5 categories:

  • Simple
  • Combinator
  • Pseudo-Class
  • Pseudo-Element
  • Attibute

The following sections will explain each one of these categories and give the neccessary examples.

Simple Selectors

Simple selectors select elements based on their name, class or id. This category also includes the universal selector and the grouping selector.

Name

A selector defined by the name of an element selects all the elements on the page with the specified name.

Target:

<div></div> <div></div>

Selector:

div{ }

Id

Each element id should be unique on a page, so this selector is used to target a specific element.

Target:

<div id="div1"></div>

Selector:

#div1{ }

Class

Classes are used to create a custom group os elements. A class can be used when only certains elements of a kind should be styled, or when the same rules must be applied to elements with different names.

Target:

<p class="red-text">Text</p> <label class="red-text">Text</label>

Selector:

.red-text{ color: red; }

Element and class

It is possible to select an element based both on it's name and class. For example, to select all divs that have the class "square", the selector would be the following:

div.square { }

Multiple Classes

To select an element that have both class1 and class2, the following selector would be used:

.class1.class2{ }

Grouping selector

Another way to select multiple kinds of elements is the grouping selector. Let's say we have the following rules:

p{ color: blue; } label{ color: blue; }

That could be written as:

p, label { color: red; }

Universal selector

The universal selector targets everything on the page. Example:

*{ font-size: 16px; }
Combinators

Combinators define relation between selectors. A CSS selector may contain more than one simple selector, and a combinator is needed to connect them.

There are four combinators:

  • Descendant (space)
  • Child (>)
  • Adjacent sibling (+)
  • General sibling (~)

Descendant

The descendant selector is used to match elements that are descendants of a specified element.

Target:

<div> <p> </p></div>

Selector:

div p{ }

Child

The child selector selects an element that have an specified parent.

Target:

<div> <p> </p></div>

Selector:

div > p{ }

Adjacent sibling

The adjacent sibling selector selects an element that is immediately preceded by an specified element. Both elements must have the same parent.

Target:

<div></div> <p> </p>

Selector (to select the p element):

div + p{ }

General sibling

The general sibling selector selects an element that is preceded by an specified element. Both elements must have the same parent.

Target:

<div> <p> </p> <label> </label> <a> </a> </div>

Selector (to select the a element):

p ~ a{ }
Pseudo-class Selectors

Pseudo-classes are special states of an element, like a hovered div or an active link. The syntax of pseudo-class selectors is as follows:

selector:pseudoclass{}

For example, to select a div with the "class1" class being hovered:

div.class1:hover {}

Pseudo classes includes a lot of features, such as selecting elements based on it's position on the parent, only childs and even the elements that are not selected by a specified selector.

To view the full list of pseudo-class selectors, visit the W3Schools site.

Pseudo-element Selectors

A pseudo-element selector targets specific parts of elements, like the first line or letter. It also can be used to insert content before and after a specified element.

The syntax is similar to pseudo classes:

selector::pseudo-element {}

To style the first letter of each paragraph, making it green:

p::first-letter{ color: green; }

To insert content before an element:

p::before { content: "example"; }
Attribute Selectors

These selectors make it possible to style elements based in its attributes or attribute values.

Attribute

To target all "a" elements with the [target] attribute specified:

a[target]{}

Attribute value

To target all "a" elements with the [target] attribute set as "_blank":

a[target=""_blank""]{}

Pattern matching

There are some selectors to select elements based on patterns of it's attributes:

Containing a specific word (~):

[title~="code"]{}

Is the exact value or the value followed by - (|):

Target: (the first two p will be styled, but the third don't)

<p class="top"></p> <p class="top-2"></p> <p class="top2"></p>

Selector:

[class|="top"]{}

Beggining with (^):

(With this selector, all p elements of the previous example would be styled)

[class^="top"]{}

Ends with ($):

[class$="top"]{}

Contains (*):

[class*="top"]{}
